contentrichtext.text: {{Selfref|For guidelines on using of this unit on Wikipedia, see [[WP:ZEBIBYTE]].}} The '''zebibyte''' is a standards-based [[binary prefix|binary multiple]] (prefix [[zebi-|''zebi'']], symbol ''Zi'') of the [[byte]], a unit of [[Computer data storage|digital information storage]]. The zebibyte unit symbol is '''ZiB'''. 1 zebibyte = 2<sup>70</sup> [[byte]]s = {{gaps|1|180|591|620|717|411|303|424|bytes}} = 1,024 [[exbibyte]]s The zebibyte is closely related to the [[zettabyte]], which is defined as 10<sup>21</sup> bytes = {{gaps|1|000|000|000|000|000|000|000|bytes}} (see [[binary prefix]]). The ''zebi'' and ''yobi'' prefixes were originally not part of the system of binary prefixes, but were added by the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] in August 2005.<ref>[http://www.iec.ch/news_centre/release/nr2005/nr2005.htm IEC - IEC in action | News releases > nr2005 - Here come zebi and yobi]</ref> ==Usage examples== * [[GUID Partition Table]] (GPT) allows for a maximum disk and partition size of 8 zebibytes, or 9.4 zettabytes, when using 512-byte [[Disk sector|sectors]].<ref name=UEFIDrivePartitionLimits>{{cite news |title=FAQ: Drive Partition Limits |publisher=UEFI Forum |url=http://www.uefi.org/learning_center/UEFI_MBR_Limits_v2.pdf |format=PDF |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref><ref name=IBMLargeDrivesGPT>{{cite news |title=Make the most of large drives with GPT and Linux |author=Roderick W. Smith |publisher=[[IBM]] |url=http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/l-gpt/ |quote=Disk pointers are 64 bits in size, meaning that GPT can handle disks of up to 512 x 264 bytes (8 zebibytes, or 8.6 billion TiB), assuming 512-byte sectors. |date=2012-07-03 |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref> ==See also== {{Quantities of bytes}} * [[zebibit]] * [[exbibyte]] * [[yobibyte]] * [[SI prefix]] * [[IEEE 1541]] * [[orders of magnitude (data)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Computer Storage Volumes}} [[Category:Units of information]]
